</ul></td></tr></tbody></table><h2> <span class="mw-headline" id="Optimization_problems">Optimization problems</span></h2>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/optimization-problem_12585_eduNitas.html" title="Optimization problem" target="_blank">Optimization problem</a></div>
<p>An optimization problem can be represented in the following way</p>
<dl><dd><i>Given:</i> a <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/function_8816_eduNitas.html" title="Function (mathematics)" target="_blank">function</a> <i>f</i> : <i>A</i> <img class="tex" alt="\to" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=da558173e1f2ddfeb273751d481f9a52.png"> <b>R</b> from some <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/set_14311_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Set (mathematics)" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">set</a> <i>A</i> to the <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/real-numbers_13720_eduNitas.html" title="Real number" target="_blank">real numbers</a></dd><dd><i>Sought:</i> an element <i>x</i><sub>0</sub> in <i>A</i> such that <i>f</i>(<i>x</i><sub>0</sub>) ≤ <i>f</i>(<i>x</i>) for all <i>x</i> in <i>A</i> ("minimization") or such that <i>f</i>(<i>x</i><sub>0</sub>) ≥ <i>f</i>(<i>x</i>) for all <i>x</i> in <i>A</i> ("maximization").</dd></dl><p>Such a formulation is called an <b><a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/optimization-problem_12585_eduNitas.html" title="Optimization problem" target="_blank">optimization problem</a></b> or a <b>mathematical programming problem</b> (a term not directly related to <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/computer-programming_1369_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Computer programming" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">computer programming</a>, but still in use for example in <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/linear-programming_10899_eduNitas.html" title="Linear programming" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">linear programming</a> - see <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/optimization_11279_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html#History" target="_blank">History</a> below). Many real-world and theoretical problems may be modeled in this general framework. Problems formulated using this technique in the fields of <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/physics_13063_eduNitas.html" title="Physics" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">physics</a> and <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/computer-vision_7099_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Computer vision" target="_blank">computer vision</a> may refer to the technique as <b>energy minimization</b>, speaking of the value of the function <i>f</i> as representing the energy of the <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/system_15129_eduNitas.html" title="System" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">system</a> being <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/modeled_10146_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Mathematical model" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">modeled</a>.</p>
<p>Typically, <i>A</i> is some <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/subset_14987_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Subset" target="_blank">subset</a> of the <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Euclidean-space_8286_eduNitas.html" title="Euclidean space" target="_blank">Euclidean space</a> <b>R</b><sup><i>n</i></sup>, often specified by a set of <i><a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/constraints_7155_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Constraint (mathematics)" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">constraints</a></i>, equalities or inequalities that the members of <i>A</i> have to satisfy. The domain <i>A</i> of <i>f</i> is called the <i>search space</i> or the <i>choice set</i>, while the elements of <i>A</i> are called <i><a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/candidate-solutions_7438_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Candidate solution" target="_blank">candidate solutions</a></i> or <i>feasible solutions</i>.</p>
<p>The function <i>f</i> is called, variously, an <b>objective function</b>, <b>cost function</b> (minimization),<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a class="ref1" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/optimization_11279_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html#cite_note-2" target="_blank"><span>[</span>2<span>]</span></a></sup> <b>indirect utility function</b> (minimization),<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a class="ref1" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/optimization_11279_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html#cite_note-3" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"><span>[</span>3<span>]</span></a></sup> <b>utility function</b> (maximization), or, in certain fields, <b>energy function</b>, or <b>energy functional</b>. A feasible solution that minimizes (or maximizes, if that is the goal) the objective function is called an <i>optimal solution</i>.</p>
<p>By convention, the standard form of an optimization problem is stated in terms of minimization. Generally, unless both the objective function and the feasible region are convex in a minimization problem, there may be several local minima, where a <i>local minimum</i> x<sup>*</sup> is defined as a point for which there exists some δ > 0 so that for all x such that</p>
<dl><dd><img class="tex" alt="\|\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{x}^*\|\leq\delta;\," src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=88e1d6622f49517dfe26d81df1bc9ecf.png"></dd></dl><p>the expression</p>
<dl><dd><img class="tex" alt="f(\mathbf{x}^*)\leq f(\mathbf{x})" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=0ec527e695b1e516f5c726d0247d5f83.png"></dd></dl><p>holds; that is to say, on some region around x<sup>*</sup> all of the function values are greater than or equal to the value at that point. Local maxima are defined similarly.</p>
<p>A large number of algorithms proposed for solving non-convex problems – including the majority of commercially available solvers – are not capable of making a distinction between local optimal solutions and rigorous optimal solutions, and will treat the former as actual solutions to the original problem. The branch of <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/applied-mathematics_5665_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Applied mathematics" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">applied mathematics</a> and <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/numerical-analysis_12277_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Numerical analysis" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">numerical analysis</a> that is concerned with the development of deterministic algorithms that are capable of guaranteeing convergence in finite time to the actual optimal solution of a non-convex problem is called <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/global-optimization_9072_eduNitas.html" title="Global optimization" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">global optimization</a>.</p>
<h2> <span class="mw-headline" id="Notation">Notation</span></h2>
<p>Optimization problems are often expressed with special notation. Here are some examples.</p>
<h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Minimum_and_maximum_value_of_a_function">Minimum and maximum value of a function</span></h3>
<p>Consider the following notation:</p>
<dl><dd><img class="tex" alt="\min_{x\in\mathbb R}\; (x^2 + 1)" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=436fa9b32750359d342d5bcb709a8ba0.png"></dd></dl><p>This denotes the minimum value of the objective function <img class="tex" alt="x^2 + 1" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=19cb4465624f301eeb8f8a6d1d60276b.png">, when choosing <i>x</i> from the set of <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/real-numbers_13720_eduNitas.html" title="Real number" target="_blank">real numbers</a> <img class="tex" alt="\mathbb R" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=0c95a37acc94ef8c093ce39c36e07886.png">. The minimum value in this case is <img class="tex" alt="1" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=c4ca4238a0b923820dcc509a6f75849b.png">, occurring at <img class="tex" alt="x = 0" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=e11729b0b65ecade3fc272548a3883fc.png">.</p>
<p>Similarly, the notation</p>
<dl><dd><img class="tex" alt="\max_{x\in\mathbb R}\; 2x" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=090550b2c9034f308c59f9d4d375a73d.png"></dd></dl><p>asks for the maximum value of the objective function 2<i>x</i>, where <i>x</i> may be any real number. In this case, there is no such maximum as the objective function is unbounded, so the answer is "infinity" or "undefined".</p>
<h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Optimal_input_arguments">Optimal input arguments</span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: Arg max</div>
<p>Consider the following notation:</p>
<dl><dd><img class="tex" alt="\underset{x\in(-\infty,-1]}{\operatorname{arg\,min}} \; x^2 + 1," src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=f356685bbb0bdac5fbffe93dc801f459.png"></dd></dl><p>or equivalently</p>
<dl><dd><img class="tex" alt="\underset{x}{\operatorname{arg\,min}} \; x^2 + 1, \; \text{subject to:} \; x\in(-\infty,-1]." src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=47a299410636b194b71cf02cc506df35.png"></dd></dl><p>This represents the value (or values) of the argument <i>x</i> in the interval <img class="tex" alt="(-\infty,-1]" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=2bbda46f09c030f245f9afe1fa0eb85f.png"> that minimizes (or minimize) the objective function <i>x</i><sup>2</sup> + 1 (the actual minimum value of that function is not what the problem asks for). In this case, the answer is <i>x</i> = -1, since <i>x</i> = 0 is infeasible, i.e. does not belong to the feasible set.</p>
<p>Similarly,</p>
<dl><dd><img class="tex" alt="\underset{x\in[-5,5], \; y\in\mathbb R}{\operatorname{arg\,max}} \; x\cos(y)," src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=073cab0bbd77ec9324992a2f56467daa.png"></dd></dl><p>or equivalently</p>
<dl><dd><img class="tex" alt="\underset{x, \; y}{\operatorname{arg\,max}} \; x\cos(y), \; \text{subject to:} \; x\in[-5,5], \; y\in\mathbb R," src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=2a1fae4789ea354904e7b3241eafc7ac.png"></dd></dl><p>represents the <img class="tex" alt="(x,y)" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=90cbc22edf225adf8a68974f51227f05.png"> pair (or pairs) that maximizes (or maximize) the value of the objective function <img class="tex" alt="x\cos(y)" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=316799a17e084a5141faa77538e39aa2.png">, with the added constraint that <i>x</i> lie in the interval <img class="tex" alt="[-5,5]" src="https://sandbox.copyleaks.com/?url=http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/_buku_manual/_baca_blob.php?book=lain&td=2&kodegb=728629d5db271bc36f160c71b422fa90.png"> (again, the actual maximum value of the expression does not matter). In this case, the solutions are the pairs of the form (5, 2k<a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/%CF%80_20881_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Pi" target="_blank">π</a>) and (−5,(2k+1)π), where <i>k</i> ranges over all <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/integers_19475_eduNitas.html" title="Integer" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">integers</a>.</p>
<p><b>Arg min</b> and <b>arg max</b> are sometimes also written <b>argmin</b> and <b>argmax</b>, and stand for <b>argument of the minimum</b> and <b>argument of the maximum</b>.</p>
<h2> <span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p>Fermat and <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/Lagrange_19722_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Joseph Louis Lagrange" target="_blank">Lagrange</a> found calculus-based formulas for identifying optima, while <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Newton_10093_eduNitas.html" title="Isaac Newton" target="_blank">Newton</a> and Gauss proposed iterative methods for moving towards an optimum. Historically, the first term for optimization was "<a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/linear-programming_10899_eduNitas.html" title="Linear programming" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">linear programming</a>", which was due to George B. Dantzig, although much of the theory had been introduced by Leonid Kantorovich in 1939. Dantzig published the <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/Simplex-algorithm_14443_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Simplex algorithm" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Simplex algorithm</a> in 1947, and <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/John-von-Neumann_2598_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="John von Neumann" target="_blank">John von Neumann</a> developed the theory of <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/duality_10899_eduNitas.html#Duality" title="Linear programming" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">duality</a> in the same year.</p>
<p>The term <i>programming</i> in this context does not refer to <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/computer-programming_1369_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Computer programming" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">computer programming</a>. Rather, the term comes from the use of <i>program</i> by the United States military to refer to proposed training and logistics schedules, which were the problems Dantzig studied at that time.</p>
<p>Later important researchers in mathematical optimization include the following:</p>
<table class="multicol" style="border-collapse: collapse; padding: 0px; border: 0px; background:transparent; width:100%;"><tbody><tr><td style="width:50%; text-align:left; vertical-align:top;"><ul><li>Richard Bellman</li>
<li>Ronald A. Howard</li>
<li>Narendra Karmarkar</li>
<li>William Karush</li>
<li>Leonid Khachiyan</li>
<li>Bernard Koopman</li>
<li>Harold Kuhn</li>
<li><a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/Lagrange_19722_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Joseph Louis Lagrange" target="_blank">Joseph Louis Lagrange</a></li>
<li>László Lovász</li>
</ul></td><td style="width:50%; text-align:left; vertical-align:top;"><ul><li>Arkadi Nemirovski</li>
<li>Yurii Nesterov</li>
<li>Boris Polyak</li>
<li>Lev Pontryagin</li>
<li>James Renegar</li>
<li>R. Tyrrell Rockafellar</li>
<li>Cornelis Roos</li>
<li>Naum Z. Shor</li>
<li>Michael J. Todd</li>
<li>Albert Tucker</li>
</ul></td></tr></tbody></table><h2> <span class="mw-headline" id="Major_subfields">Major subfields</span></h2>
<ul><li>Convex programming studies the case when the objective function is convex (minimization) or concave (maximization) and the constraint set is convex. This can be viewed as a particular case of nonlinear programming or as generalization of linear or convex quadratic programming.<ul><li><a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/linear-programming_10899_eduNitas.html" title="Linear programming" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Linear programming</a> (LP), a type of convex programming, studies the case in which the objective function <i>f</i> is linear and the set of constraints is specified using only linear equalities and inequalities. Such a set is called a polyhedron or a polytope if it is bounded.</li>
<li>Second order cone programming (SOCP) is a convex program, and includes certain types of quadratic programs.</li>
<li>Semidefinite programming (SDP) is a subfield of convex optimization where the underlying variables are semidefinite <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/matrices_11288_eduNitas.html" title="Matrix (mathematics)" target="_blank">matrices</a>. It is generalization of linear and convex quadratic programming.</li>
<li>Conic programming is a general form of convex programming. LP, SOCP and SDP can all be viewed as conic programs with the appropriate type of cone.</li>
<li>Geometric programming is a technique whereby objective and inequality constraints expressed as posynomials and equality constraints as monomials can be transformed into a convex program.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Integer programming studies linear programs in which some or all variables are constrained to take on <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/integers_19475_eduNitas.html" title="Integer" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">integer</a> values. This is not convex, and in general much more difficult than regular linear programming.</li>
<li><a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Quadratic-programming_13549_eduNitas.html" title="Quadratic programming" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Quadratic programming</a> allows the objective function to have quadratic terms, while the feasible set must be specified with linear equalities and inequalities. For specific forms of the quadratic term, this is a type of convex programming.</li>
<li>Fractional programming studies optimization of ratios of two nonlinear functions. The special class of concave fractional programs can be transformed to a convex optimization problem.</li>
<li><a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Nonlinear-programming_12199_eduNitas.html" title="Nonlinear programming" target="_blank">Nonlinear programming</a> studies the general case in which the objective function or the constraints or both contain nonlinear parts. This may or may not be a convex program. In general, whether the program is convex affects the difficulty of solving it.</li>
<li>Stochastic programming studies the case in which some of the constraints or parameters depend on random variables.</li>
<li>Robust programming is, like stochastic programming, an attempt to capture uncertainty in the data underlying the optimization problem. This is not done through the use of random variables, but instead, the problem is solved taking into account inaccuracies in the input data.</li>
<li><a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/Combinatorial-optimization_6974_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Combinatorial optimization" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Combinatorial optimization</a> is concerned with problems where the set of feasible solutions is discrete or can be reduced to a <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/discrete_7777_eduNitas.html" title="Discrete mathematics" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">discrete</a> one.</li>
<li>Stochastic optimization for use with random (noisy) function measurements or random inputs in the search process.</li>
<li>Infinite-dimensional optimization studies the case when the set of feasible solutions is a subset of an infinite-dimensional space, such as a space of functions.</li>
<li><a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Heuristics_19231_eduNitas.html" title="Heuristic (computer science)" target="_blank">Heuristics</a> and metaheuristics make few or no assumptions about the problem being optimized. Usually, heuristics do not guarantee that any optimal solution need be found. On the other hand, heuristics are used to find approximate solutions for many complicated optimization problems.</li>
<li>Constraint satisfaction studies the case in which the objective function <i>f</i> is constant (this is used in <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/artificial-intelligence_5752_eduNitas.html" title="Artificial intelligence" target="_blank">artificial intelligence</a>, particularly in <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/automated-reasoning_5884_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Automated reasoning" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">automated reasoning</a>).<ul><li><a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Constraint-programming_7157_eduNitas.html" title="Constraint programming" target="_blank">Constraint programming</a>.</li>
</ul></li>
<li>Disjunctive programming is used where at least one constraint must be satisfied but not all. It is of particular use in scheduling.</li>
</ul><p>In a number of subfields, the techniques are designed primarily for optimization in dynamic contexts (that is, decision making over time):</p>
<ul><li>Calculus of variations seeks to optimize an objective defined over many points in time, by considering how the objective function changes if there is a small change in the choice path.</li>
<li>Optimal control theory is a generalization of the calculus of variations.</li>
<li><a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/Dynamic-programming_7987_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Dynamic programming" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Dynamic programming</a> studies the case in which the optimization strategy is based on splitting the problem into smaller subproblems. The equation that describes the relationship between these subproblems is called the Bellman equation.</li>
<li>Mathematical programming with equilibrium constraints is where the constraints include variational inequalities or complementarities.</li>
</ul><h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Multi-objective_optimization">Multi-objective optimization</span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: Multi-objective optimization</div>
<p>Adding more than one objective to an optimization problem adds complexity. For example, to optimize a structural design, one would want a design that is both light and rigid. Because these two objectives conflict, a trade-off exists. There will be one lightest design, one stiffest design, and an infinite number of designs that are some compromise of weight and stiffness. The set of trade-off designs that cannot be improved upon according to one criterion without hurting another criterion is known as the Pareto set. The curve created plotting weight against stiffness of the best designs is known as the Pareto frontier.</p>
<p>A design is judged to be "Pareto optimal" (equivalently, "Pareto efficient" or in the Pareto set) if it is not dominated by any other design: If it is worse than another design in some respects and no better in any respect, then it is dominated and is not Pareto optimal.</p>
<p>The choice among "Pareto optimal" solutions to determine the "favorite solution" is delegated to the decision maker. In other words, defining the problem as multiobjective optimization signals that some information is missing: desirable objectives are given but not their detailed combination. In some cases, the missing information can be derived by interactive sessions with the decision maker.</p>
<p>Multi-objective optimization problems have been generalized further to vector optimization problems where the (partial) ordering is no longer given by the Pareto ordering.</p>
<h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Multi-modal_optimization">Multi-modal optimization</span></h3>
<p>Optimization problems are often multi-modal; that is, they possess multiple good solutions. They could all be globally good (same cost function value) or there could be a mix of globally good and locally good solutions. Obtaining all (or at least some of) the multiple solutions is the goal of a multi-modal optimizer.</p>
<p>Classical optimization techniques due to their iterative approach do not perform satisfactorily when they are used to obtain multiple solutions, since it is not guaranteed that different solutions will be obtained even with different starting points in multiple runs of the algorithm. Evolutionary Algorithms are however a very popular approach to obtain multiple solutions in a multi-modal optimization task. See Evolutionary multi-modal optimization.</p>
<h2> <span class="mw-headline" id="Classification_of_critical_points_and_extrema">Classification of critical points and extrema</span></h2>
<h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Feasibility_problem">Feasibility problem</span></h3>
<p>The <b>satisfiability problem</b>, also called the <b>feasibility problem</b>, is just the problem of finding any <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/candidate-solutions_7438_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Feasible solution" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">feasible solution</a> at all without regard to objective value. This can be regarded as the special case of mathematical optimization where the objective value is the same for every solution, and thus any solution is optimal.</p>
<p>Many optimization algorithms need to start from a feasible point. One way to obtain such a point is to relax the feasibility conditions using a slack variable; with enough slack, any starting point is feasible. Then, minimize that slack variable until slack is null or negative.</p>
<h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Existence">Existence</span></h3>
<p>The extreme value theorem of Karl Weierstrass states that a continuous real-valued function on a compact set attains its maximum and minimum value. More generally, a lower semi-continuous function on a compact set attains its minimum; an upper semi-continuous function on a compact set attains its maximum.</p>
<h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Necessary_conditions_for_optimality">Necessary conditions for optimality</span></h3>
<p>One of Fermat's theorems states that optima of unconstrained problems are found at stationary points, where the first derivative or the gradient of the objective function is zero (see first derivative test). More generally, they may be found at critical points, where the first derivative or gradient of the objective function is zero or is undefined, or on the boundary of the choice set. An equation (or set of equations) stating that the first derivative(s) equal(s) zero at an interior optimum is called a 'first-order condition' or a set of first-order conditions.</p>
<p>Optima of inequality-constrained problems are instead found by the <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/Lagrange-multiplier_10729_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Lagrange multiplier" target="_blank">Lagrange multiplier</a> method. This method calculates a system of inequalities called the 'Karush–Kuhn–Tucker conditions' or 'complementary slackness conditions', which may then be used to calculate the optimum.</p>
<h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Sufficient_conditions_for_optimality">Sufficient conditions for optimality</span></h3>
<p>While the first derivative test identifies points that might be extrema, this test does not distinguish a point that is a minimum from one that is a maximum or one that is neither. When the objective function is twice differentiable, these cases can be distinguished by checking the second derivative or the matrix of second derivatives (called the Hessian matrix) in unconstrained problems, or the matrix of second derivatives of the objective function and the constraints called the bordered Hessian in constrained problems. The conditions that distinguish maxima, or minima, from other stationary points are called 'second-order conditions' (see 'Second derivative test'). If a candidate solution satisfies the first-order conditions, then satisfaction of the second-order conditions as well is sufficient to establish at least local optimality.</p>
<h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Sensitivity_and_continuity_of_optima">Sensitivity and continuity of optima</span></h3>
<p>The envelope theorem describes how the value of an optimal solution changes when an underlying parameter changes. The process of computing this change is called comparative statics.</p>
<p>The maximum theorem of Claude Berge (1963) describes the continuity of an optimal solution as a function of underlying parameters.</p>
<h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Calculus_of_optimization">Calculus of optimization</span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: Karush–Kuhn–Tucker conditions</div>
<div class="rellink boilerplate seealso">See also: Critical point (mathematics), Differential calculus, <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Gradient_2176_eduNitas.html" title="Gradient" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Gradient</a>, Hessian matrix, Positive definite matrix, Lipschitz continuity, Rademacher's theorem, Convex function, and Convex analysis</div>
<p>For unconstrained problems with twice-differentiable functions, some critical points can be found by finding the points where the <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Gradient_2176_eduNitas.html" title="Gradient" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">gradient</a> of the objective function is zero (that is, the stationary points). More generally, a zero subgradient certifies that a local minimum has been found for minimization problems with convex functions and other locally Lipschitz functions.</p>
<p>Further, critical points can be classified using the definiteness of the Hessian matrix: If the Hessian is <i>positive</i> definite at a critical point, then the point is a local minimum; if the Hessian matrix is negative definite, then the point is a local maximum; finally, if indefinite, then the point is some kind of saddle point.</p>
<p>Constrained problems can often be transformed into unconstrained problems with the help of <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/Lagrange-multiplier_10729_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Lagrange multiplier" target="_blank">Lagrange multipliers</a>. Lagrangian relaxation can also provide approximate solutions to difficult constrained problems.</p>
<p>When the objective function is convex, then any local minimum will also be a global minimum. There exist efficient numerical techniques for minimizing convex functions, such as interior-point methods.</p>
<h2> <span class="mw-headline" id="Computational_optimization_techniques">Computational optimization techniques</span></h2>
<p>To solve problems, researchers may use <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/algorithms_393_eduNitas.html" title="Algorithm" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">algorithms</a> that terminate in a finite number of steps, or <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/iterative-methods_10122_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Iterative method" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">iterative methods</a> that converge to a solution (on some specified class of problems), or <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Heuristics_19231_eduNitas.html" title="Heuristic algorithm" target="_blank">heuristics</a> that may provide approximate solutions to some problems (although their iterates need not converge).</p>
<h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Optimization_algorithms">Optimization algorithms</span></h3>
<ul><li><a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/Simplex-algorithm_14443_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Simplex algorithm" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Simplex algorithm</a> of George Dantzig, designed for <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/linear-programming_10899_eduNitas.html" title="Linear programming" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">linear programming</a>.</li>
<li>Extensions of the simplex algorithm, designed for <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Quadratic-programming_13549_eduNitas.html" title="Quadratic programming" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">quadratic programming</a> and for linear-fractional programming.</li>
<li>Variants of the simplex algorithm that are especially suited for <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/network-optimization_18878_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Flow network" target="_blank">network optimization</a>.</li>
<li><a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/Combinatorial-optimization_6974_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Combinatorial optimization" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Combinatorial algorithms</a></li>
</ul><h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Iterative_methods">Iterative methods</span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/iterative-methods_10122_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Iterative method" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Iterative method</a></div>
<div class="rellink boilerplate seealso">See also: <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/Newton's-method_12124_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Newton's method" target="_blank">Newton's method</a>, Quasi-Newton method, <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/Finite-difference_8539_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Finite difference" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Finite difference</a>, Approximation theory, and <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/numerical-analysis_12277_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Numerical analysis" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Numerical analysis</a></div>
<p>The iterative methods used to solve problems of <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Nonlinear-programming_12199_eduNitas.html" title="Nonlinear programming" target="_blank">nonlinear programming</a> differ according to whether they <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/evaluate_4234_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Subroutine" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">evaluate</a> Hessians, gradients, or only function values. While evaluating Hessians (H) and gradients (G) improves the rate of convergence, for functions for which these quantities exist and vary sufficiently smoothly, such evaluations increase the computational complexity (or computational cost) of each iteration. In some cases, the computational complexity may be excessively high.</p>
<p>One major criterion for optimizers is just the number of required function evaluations as this often is already a large computational effort, usually much more effort than within the optimizer itself, which mainly has to operate over the N variables. The derivatives provide detailed information for such optimizers, but are even harder to calculate, e.g. approximating the gradient takes at least N+1 function evaluations. For approximations of the 2nd derivatives (collected in the Hessian matrix) the number of function evaluations is in the order of N2. Newton's method requires the 2nd order derivates, so for each iteration the number of function calls is in the order of N2, but for a simpler pure gradient optimizer it is only N. However, gradient optimizers need usually more iterations than Newton's algorithm. Which one is best with respect to the number of function calls depends on the problem itself.</p>
<ul><li>Methods that evaluate Hessians (or approximate Hessians, using <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/Finite-difference_8539_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Finite difference" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">finite differences</a>):<ul><li>Newton's method<ul><li>Sequential quadratic programming: A Newton-based method for small-medium scale <i>constrained</i> problems. Some versions can handle large-dimensional problems.</li>
</ul></li>
</ul></li>
</ul><ul><li>Methods that evaluate gradients or approximate gradients using finite differences (or even subgradients):<ul><li>Quasi-Newton methods: Iterative methods for medium-large problems (e.g. N<1000).</li>
<li><a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Conjugate-gradient-methods_7137_eduNitas.html" title="Conjugate gradient method" target="_blank">Conjugate gradient methods</a>: <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/iterative-methods_10122_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Iterative method" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Iterative methods</a> for large problems. (In theory, these methods terminate in a finite number of steps with quadratic objective functions, but this finite termination is not observed in practice on finite–precision computers.)</li>
<li>Interior point methods: This is a large class of methods for constrained optimization. Some interior-point methods use only (sub)gradient information, and others of which require the evaluation of Hessians.</li>
<li>Gradient descent (alternatively, "steepest descent" or "steepest ascent"): A (slow) method of historical and theoretical interest, which has had renewed interest for finding approximate solutions of enormous problems.</li>
<li>Subgradient methods - An iterative method for large locally Lipschitz functions using generalized gradients. Following Boris T. Polyak, subgradient–projection methods are similar to conjugate–gradient methods.</li>
<li>Bundle method of descent: An iterative method for small–medium sized problems with locally Lipschitz functions, particularly for convex minimization problems. (Similar to conjugate gradient methods)</li>
<li>Ellipsoid method: An iterative method for small problems with quasiconvex objective functions and of great theoretical interest, particularly in establishing the polynomial time complexity of some combinatorial optimization problems. It has similarities with Quasi-Newton methods.</li>
<li>Reduced gradient method (Frank–Wolfe) for approximate minimization of specially structured problems with linear constraints, especially with traffic networks. For general unconstrained problems, this method reduces to the gradient method, which is regarded as obsolete (for almost all problems).</li>
<li>Simultaneous perturbation stochastic approximation (SPSA) method for stochastic optimization; uses random (efficient) gradient approximation.</li>
</ul></li>
</ul><ul><li>Methods that evaluate only function values: If a problem is continuously differentiable, then gradients can be approximated using finite differences, in which case a gradient-based method can be used.<ul><li><a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/Interpolation_10015_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Interpolation" target="_blank">Interpolation</a> methods</li>
<li>Pattern search methods, which have better convergence properties than the Nelder–Mead heuristic (with simplices), which is listed below.</li>
</ul></li>
</ul><h4> <span class="mw-headline" id="Global_convergence">Global convergence</span></h4>
<p>More generally, if the objective function is not a quadratic function, then many optimization methods use other methods to ensure that some subsequence of iterations converges to an optimal solution. The first and still popular method for ensuring convergence relies on line searches, which optimize a function along one dimension. A second and increasingly popular method for ensuring convergence uses trust regions. Both line searches and trust regions are used in modern methods of non-differentiable optimization. Usually a global optimizer is much slower than advanced local optimizers (such as BFGS), so often an efficient global optimizer can be constructed by starting the local optimizer from different starting points.</p>
<h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Heuristics">Heuristics</span></h3>
<div class="rellink relarticle mainarticle">Main article: <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Heuristics_19231_eduNitas.html" title="Heuristic algorithm" target="_blank">Heuristic algorithm</a></div>
<p>Besides (finitely terminating) <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/algorithms_393_eduNitas.html" title="Algorithm" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">algorithms</a> and (convergent) <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/iterative-methods_10122_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Iterative method" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">iterative methods</a>, there are <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Heuristics_19231_eduNitas.html" title="Heuristic algorithm" target="_blank">heuristics</a> that can provide approximate solutions to some optimization problems:</p>
<ul><li>Memetic algorithm</li>
<li>Differential evolution</li>
<li>Differential Search algorithm <sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a class="ref1" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/optimization_11279_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html#cite_note-4" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"><span>[</span>4<span>]</span></a></sup> Matlab code-link has been provided in Çivicioglu, P.,(2012).</li>
<li>Dynamic relaxation</li>
<li><a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/Genetic-algorithms_19014_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Genetic algorithms" target="_blank">Genetic algorithms</a></li>
<li><a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Hill-climbing_19246_eduNitas.html" title="Hill climbing" target="_blank">Hill climbing</a></li>
<li>Nelder-Mead simplicial heuristic: A popular heuristic for approximate minimization (without calling gradients)</li>
<li><a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Particle-swarm-optimization_20758_eduNitas.html" title="Particle swarm optimization" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Particle swarm optimization</a></li>
<li>Artificial bee colony optimization</li>
<li><a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/Simulated-annealing_14453_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Simulated annealing" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Simulated annealing</a></li>
<li>Tabu search</li>
<li>Reactive Search Optimization (RSO)<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a class="ref1" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/optimization_11279_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html#cite_note-5" target="_blank"><span>[</span>5<span>]</span></a></sup> implemented in <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/LIONsolver_10955_eduNitas.html" title="LIONsolver" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">LIONsolver</a></li>
</ul><h2> <span class="mw-headline" id="Applications">Applications</span></h2>
<h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Mechanics_and_engineering">Mechanics and engineering</span></h3>
<p>Problems in rigid body dynamics (in particular articulated rigid body dynamics) often require mathematical programming techniques, since you can view rigid body dynamics as attempting to solve an <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/ordinary-differential-equation_12624_eduNitas.html" title="Ordinary differential equation" target="_blank">ordinary differential equation</a> on a constraint manifold; the constraints are various nonlinear geometric constraints such as "these two points must always coincide", "this surface must not penetrate any other", or "this point must always lie somewhere on this curve". Also, the problem of computing contact forces can be done by solving a linear complementarity problem, which can also be viewed as a QP (quadratic programming) problem.</p>
<p>Many design problems can also be expressed as optimization programs. This application is called design optimization. One subset is the engineering optimization, and another recent and growing subset of this field is multidisciplinary design optimization, which, while useful in many problems, has in particular been applied to <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/aerospace-engineering_17084_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Aerospace engineering" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">aerospace engineering</a> problems.</p>
<h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Economics">Economics</span></h3>
<p><a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/Economics_18562_eduNitas.html" title="Economics" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">Economics</a> is closely enough linked to optimization of agents that an influential definition relatedly describes economics <i>qua</i> science as the "study of human behavior as a relationship between ends and scarce means" with alternative uses.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a class="ref1" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/optimization_11279_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html#cite_note-6" target="_blank"><span>[</span>6<span>]</span></a></sup> Modern optimization theory includes traditional optimization theory but also overlaps with <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/game-theory_8876_eduNitas.html" title="Game theory" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">game theory</a> and the study of economic equilibria. The <i>Journal of Economic Literature</i> codes classify mathematical programming, optimization techniques, and related topics under JEL:C61-C63.</p>
<p>In microeconomics, the utility maximization problem and its dual problem, the expenditure minimization problem, are economic optimization problems. Insofar as they behave consistently, consumers are assumed to maximize their <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/utility_15967_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Utility" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">utility</a>, while <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/firms_17602_eduNitas.html" title="Firm" target="_blank">firms</a> are usually assumed to maximize their profit. Also, agents are often modeled as being risk-averse, thereby preferring to avoid risk. Asset prices are also modeled using optimization theory, though the underlying mathematics relies on optimizing stochastic processes rather than on static optimization. Trade theory also uses optimization to explain trade patterns between nations. The optimization of market portfolios is an example of multi-objective optimization in economics.</p>
<p>Since the 1970s, economists have modeled dynamic decisions over time using <a class="ada" href="https://wiki.edunitas.com/IT/114-10/control-theory_7192_eduNitas.html" title="Control theory" target="_blank">control theory</a>. For example, microeconomists use <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/Dynamic-programming_7987_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Dynamic programming" rel="nofollow" target="_blank">dynamic</a> search models to study labor-market behavior.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a class="ref1" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/optimization_11279_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html#cite_note-7" target="_blank"><span>[</span>7<span>]</span></a></sup> A crucial distinction is between deterministic and stochastic models.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a class="ref1" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/optimization_11279_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html#cite_note-8" target="_blank"><span>[</span>8<span>]</span></a></sup> Macroeconomists build dynamic stochastic general equilibrium (DSGE) models that describe the dynamics of the whole economy as the result of the interdependent optimizing decisions of workers, consumers, investors, and governments.<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a class="ref1" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/optimization_11279_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html#cite_note-9" rel="nofollow" target="_blank"><span>[</span>9<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a class="ref1" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/optimization_11279_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html#cite_note-10" target="_blank"><span>[</span>10<span>]</span></a></sup></p>
<h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Operations_research">Operations research</span></h3>
<p>Another field that uses optimization techniques extensively is <a class="ada" href="http://s2-master-pps-terempa.ggkarir.co.id/IT/2182-2061/management-science_12568_s2-master-pps-terempa-ggkarir.html" title="Operations research" target="_blank">operations research</a>. Operations research also uses stochastic modeling and simulation to support improved decision-making. Increasingly, operations research uses stochastic programming to model dynamic decisions that adapt to events; such problems can be solved with large-scale optimization and stochastic optimization methods.</p>
<h3> <span class="mw-headline" id="Control_engineering">Control engineering</span></h3>
<p>Mathematical optimization is used in much modern controller design. High-level controllers such as Model predictive control (MPC) or Real-Time Optimization (RTO) employ mathematical optimization. These algorithms run online and repeatedly determine values for decision variables, such as choke openings in a process plant, by iteratively solving a mathematical optimization problem including constraints and a model of the system to be controlled.</p>
